column4: hi... I am trying to migrate to ubuntu... I want to write a very simple script with 2 commands in it... what extention do I need to run 2 terminal commands? Need to know the linux equivalent of .bat
.bash?
change it to an executable file with the chmod command
then, run the script by typing the path and file name, or  " ./filename " instead.  Most people use .sh as a common script "file extension", although it is unnecessary, technically.
need to run it from the command line interface (terminal) to see the output
you don't need #!/bin/sh as the first line, by the way, nor renaming with .sh
ahh :( just trying to follow advice
good advice, but I'm just tryiing to make it easy for you to get it right
it is just one command! I just want to run it by double clicking.... it would be quicker for me to type the command than have to go to console and do that every time :(
Are you in a terminal when you run this script, or are you trying to double click it?

I want to run one command that does metacity --replace and one that does compiz --replace so I can quickly enable and disable it whilst keeping all my settings because I have a old windows app that I need for work that is not compatible with it... but I dont want to get rid of compiz! I love it
ah - there we go.  well, go into a command prompt and see what the error is
I went to terminal and when I type normal.sh it just says command not found :(
type " ./normal.sh " like I said before
I know I can just type compiz --replace, but I really want to have it as a desktop icon I can just click on... it is a learning experience, but annoying
sorry, I missed that one... ok that works fine.... but how do I do that from a icon?
okay, try this now:  right click on your GNOME Panel (with the menu), and do Add to Panel, then click on Create Launcher
then type in the full name of the script, " /home/blahyouruser/normal.sh " and you might have to run it as Type "Application in Terminal"
I clicked on browse, found it and it works fine!
see you around!
I have to say.... and dont hate me... that is the one thing so far I still like about windows.... create a file, call it .bat and run!.... but I wouldnt go back for anything!
it's called freedom - you'll learn to like it  ;-)
